#Text=Bagrationi , wife of John IV of Trebizond
#Text=Bagrationi
#Text=( c. 1411/2 – before 1438 ) was the first Empress consort of John IV of Trebizond .
#Text=Her name is unknown .
#Text=Family
#Text=She was a daughter of King Alexander I of Georgia and his first wife Dulandukht , the daughter of Beshken II Orbeliani . [ 1 ]
#Text=Dulandukht had died or was repudiated before 1415 , when Alexander married his second wife , the heiress of Imereti , daughter of Alexander I of Imereti . [ 2 ]
#Text=Empress
#Text=In about 1426 , she married John IV of Trebizond , the son of Emperor Alexios IV of Trebizond and Theodora Kantakouzene , who had fled from Trebizond after a violent episode . [ 3 ]

#Text=According to a passage considered to be an interpolation in the history of Laonikos Chalkokondyles , he had accused his mother Theodora of having an affair with an unnamed protovestarios , whom he killed , then held his parents captive in the citadel until the palace staff released them . [ 4 ]
#Text=Sometime after marrying Bagrationi , John left Georgia for Caffa , where he sought to charter a large galley and its crew .
#Text=By 1429 he had found one , for in that year he returned to Trebizond .
#Text=Alexios IV prepared to face his son in the battlefield .
#Text=John suborned some of his father 's retainers , who assassinated Alexios IV while he slept .
#Text=He executed the assassins of his father in order to deny any connection with them , then succeeded his father , presumably with Bagrationi as his Empress . [ 5 ]
#Text=Their daughter Theodora Komnene was betrothed to Uzun Hassan of Ak Koyunlu in 1457 , whom she married the next year .
#Text=According to Anthony Bryer , this is the " most celebrated Trapezuntine-Muslim marriage " , and for which the terms of their marriage can be determined .

column1: #Text=These terms included : a dowry of properties in the villages of Halanik and Sesera ; a " bride-price " in that Uzun Hassan would extend some kind of effort to help defend Trebizond ; Theodora 's right to continue to profess the Christian faith , keep a chaplain , and act as protector of Christians subject to Uzun Hassan ; and " as it turned out , Theodora 's considerable ( and probably unusual ) right to influence Akkoyunlu foreign relations " Theodora 's tomb in Diyarbekir was shown to an Italian visitor in 1507 .
#Text=Her two daughters found their way to Damascus where Caterino Zeno met them in 1512 . [ 6 ]
#Text=An account by Caterino Zeno dated to 1474 names another daughter , Eudokia-Valenza of Trebizond .
#Text=This Valenza was a reported wife of Niccolò Crispo , Lord of Syros .
#Text=However she is reported as having a daughter who married in 1429 .
#Text=John IV and her are unlikely to have been the grandparents of a married woman only three years following their own marriage .
#Text=Valenza is considered likely to have been a sister of John IV , instead of a daughter . [ 7 ]
#Text=Niccolò Crispo had eleven children .
#Text=According to his own correspondence , Niccolò was also a son-in-law of Jacopo of Lesbos .
#Text=His children could be from either of his two marriages .
#Text=They included ( among others ) Francesco II Crispo , Duke of the Archipelago and Fiorenza Crispo , mother of Catherine Cornaro .
#Text=Death
#Text=According to the Europäische Stammtafeln : Stammtafeln zur Geschichte der Europäischen Staaten ( 1978 ) by Detlev Schwennicke , she was dead by 1438 .
#Text=John IV went on to marry an unnamed Turkish lady .
#Text=The Europäische Stammtafeln considers this second wife to have been a daughter of Dawlat Berdi .
#Text=Pero Tafur
#Text=, in his travel memoirs , records that when he visited Trebizond in 1438 John IV had a Turkish wife . [ 8 ]
